    <item>
      <title>Brendan Cole: just how bad is the ‘bad boy of Strictly’?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/lostinshowbiz/2018/feb/01/brendan-cole-just-how-bad-is-the-bad-boy-of-strictly</link>
      <description><p>Bad boys, bad boys, what you gonna do? Well, if you ask the BBC, bin them off your primetime dancing programme</p><p>‘If you were to die and come back as a person or thing,” <a href="https://www.vanityfair.com/culture/2018/01/jim-broadbent-answers-the-proust-questionnaire">Vanity Fair wonders</a> this month of the great Jim Broadbent, “what do you think it would be?” “Probably stationery,” replies Broadbent.</p><p>Well, quite. On the off-chance that even a thousandth of the crazy shit <a href="https://www.express.co.uk/celebrity-news/488096/The-many-lives-of-Shirley-MacLaine">Shirley MacLaine’s been claiming</a> for years is accurate, we’re still all going to be reincarnated as fruit flies or whatever. But I need to put it on record that, in the event I am given the choice, I would like to come back as any form of high-camp “bad boy”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/lostinshowbiz/2018/feb/01/brendan-cole-just-how-bad-is-the-bad-boy-of-strictly">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>BBC drops Brendan Cole from Strictly Come Dancing</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2018/jan/30/bbc-drops-brendan-cole-from-strictly-come-dancing</link>
      <description><p>Professional dancer joined show at launch in 2004, but has sparred with judges</p><p>The professional dancer Brendan Cole has announced that he has been dropped by the BBC from Strictly Come Dancing.</p><p>Cole, who joined the show when it launched in 2004, said he was not part of the vision for the future of the BBC One show and expressed his shock at the decision.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/dec/18/strictly-come-dancing-best-bits-joe-mcfadden">Alexandra's jive to judge Shirley: the best bits of Strictly Come Dancing 2017</a> </p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Sad news from my dance partner <a href="https://twitter.com/BrendanCole?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">@BrendanCole</a> this morning that he won’t be a part of <a href="https://twitter.com/bbcstrictly?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">@bbcstrictly</a> anymore. What an end of an era - he’s been such an integral part of the show since it started 15 series ago. It won’t be the same without him </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2018/jan/30/bbc-drops-brendan-cole-from-strictly-come-dancing">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Greg Dyke criticises 'pompous' politicians over ratings comments</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2018/jan/30/greg-dyke-criticises-pompous-politicians-over-ratings-comments</link>
      <description><p>Former BBC director general questions critics who rail against airing of popular programmes </p><p>Greg Dyke, the former director general of the BBC, has criticised politicians who accuse broadcasters of chasing TV ratings as “pompous”.</p><p>Dyke said that one of the “great myths” about television was that winning ratings was easy and questioned critics who try to stop broadcasters going downmarket to win audiences.</p><p>One of the great myths propagated by people who observe television from the outside is that getting ratings is easy</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2018/jan/30/greg-dyke-criticises-pompous-politicians-over-ratings-comments">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>The couple's six-year-old daughter, Blue Ivy, seems to tell her parents to be quiet and stop clapping with a graceful hand gesture while the singer Camila Cabello is speaking.     <item>
      <title>UK's live entertainment industry hits new highs</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2018/jan/19/uks-live-entertainment-industry-hits-new-highs</link>
      <description><p>Sector takes record £17bn in revenues last year as analysts predict further growth for 2018</p><p>The West End debut of the hit<a href="https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2017/dec/24/hamilton-west-end-observer-review"> Broadway musical Hamilton</a>, mega gigs including U2 and Guns N’ Roses and the return of Star Wars helped propel the UK’s live entertainment sector to a record £17bn in revenues last year.</p><p>Growth will continue this year as the UK’s live economy – which ranges from cinema visits to attending music and arts festivals, sports events, and live tours of TV shows including The X Factor – is forecast to surge by another £400m.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2018/jan/19/uks-live-entertainment-industry-hits-new-highs">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>We laugh at Russian propaganda. But Hollywood history is just as fake | Simon Jenkins</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/jan/11/hollywood-history-churchill-getty-trust-fiction</link>
      <description>From Churchill to Getty, the trust we rely on to interpret the world is being corroded by an entertainment industry that has lost faith in fiction<p>She staggers on to the screen,&nbsp;blood streaming from her face. Some of her wounds are flesh ones, but others are deep. Nobody cares, because her performance is sensational. Her name is truth, and she has taken a terrible beating.</p><p>The new thriller <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2017/dec/19/all-the-money-in-the-world-review-getty-kevin-spacey-christopher-plummer-ridley-scott" title="">All the Money in the World</a>, based on the kidnap of John Paul Getty III in 1973, carries an announcement that it is “inspired by” true events and that its genre is “history”. What does that mean, since some of it is clearly not true? Why not say it is “inspired by lies”, and its genre is fiction? That would be true.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/jan/08/churchill-genius-working-class-radicalism-darkest-hour-wartime-labour-pro-fascist-british-elite">Churchill’s genius was understanding how to keep working-class radicalism in check | Paul Mason</a> </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/jan/07/fire-fury-donald-trump-michael-wolff-book">Fire and Fury? Maybe Donald Trump is only just getting started | Matthew d’Ancona</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/jan/11/hollywood-history-churchill-getty-trust-fiction">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Channel 4: a new year, a new boss – and maybe a new city</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2018/jan/07/channel-4-new-year-new-boss-maybe-new-city</link>
      <description><p>The broadcaster’s recently arrived management team are expecrted to stir the creative pot – but they must also reach agreement on plans for relocation</p><p>This promises to be a big year for Channel 4. Over the next 12 months a new management team will make its mark, while the debate about whether the broadcaster moves outside London should also finally be resolved.</p><p>As a result, Channel 4 could look a substantially different organisation at the end of 2018 compared to today.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2018/jan/07/channel-4-new-year-new-boss-maybe-new-city">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Ed Miliband's pub quiz of 2017</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/2017/dec/20/ed-milibands-pub-quiz-of-2017</link>
      <description><p>Why was a massive courgette in the news? Who couldn’t face the thought of yet another election? Which death metal band did our quizmaster jam with? The former Labour leader lays down an eclectic end-of-year challenge ...</p><p>So, 2016 was the year everyone died and 2017 was … worse. Brexit chaos, North Korean nukes, nearly a year of Donald Trump’s presidency. Congratulations on having survived. And there are 280 characters on Twitter, so it’s all OK. Try this Peak 2017 Miliverse quiz and test your knowledge of the year about to end. No cheating, copying, Googling, Facebooking or Russian bots please.</p><p class="question__text"> Who said: “Our movement is a movement built on love”?</p><p class="answer__text">Jeremy Corbyn. </p><p class="answer__text">Donald Trump. </p><p class="answer__text">Justin Trudeau.</p><p class="answer__text">Kanye West.</p><p class="question__text">Who said: “Not another one!” about the prospect of the 2017 general election?</p><p class="answer__text">Theresa from No 10.</p><p class="answer__text">Betsy from Blackpool.</p><p class="answer__text">Bridget from Birmingham.</p><p class="answer__text">Brenda from Bristol. </p><p class="question__text">Who did 10-day White House communications director Anthony Scaramucci say had “cock-blocked” him for six months?</p><p class="answer__text">Steve Bannon.</p><p class="answer__text">Reince Priebus.</p><p class="answer__text">Jared Kushner.</p><p class="answer__text">Paul Ryan.</p><p class="question__text">Who said: “I believe the problem that Theresa May has is that those who defended Brexit have never explained to the British people what the consequences are”?</p><p class="answer__text">Xi Jinping.</p><p class="answer__text">Emmanuel Macron.</p><p class="answer__text">Anna Soubry.</p><p class="answer__text">Dougal from the Magic Roundabout.</p><p class="question__text">Who called whom a “sick puppy”? </p><p class="answer__text">Paul O’Grady about his dog Krystal.</p><p class="answer__text">Piers Morgan about Gary Lineker.</p><p class="answer__text">Kim Kardashian about Taylor Swift.</p><p class="answer__text">Donald Trump about Kim Jong-un. </p><p class="question__text">Theresa May memorably said what during the 2017 general election campaign as her social care policy unravelled?</p><p class="answer__text">“My circuits have malfunctioned … my circuits have malfunctioned … my circuits …”</p><p class="answer__text">“We’re in deep doo-doo. I told Lynton this election was a terrible idea.”</p><p class="answer__text">“Nothing has changed. Nothing has changed.”</p><p class="answer__text"> “Find Boris and get me a wheat field.”</p><p class="question__text">Donald Trump Jr said he couldn’t reveal to Congress the contents of his conversation with his father about a meeting with the Russians in June 2016 because:</p><p class="answer__text">Of attorney-client privilege.</p><p class="answer__text">Of a pinky promise not to.</p><p class="answer__text">It never happened.</p><p class="answer__text">He couldn’t remember.</p><p class="question__text">Jeremy Corbyn is described by some of his most ardent supporters as:</p><p class="answer__text">Obi Jez Kenobi.</p><p class="answer__text">The chosen one.</p><p class="answer__text">The absolute boy.</p><p class="answer__text">Jez the lad.</p><p class="question__text">What was Hillary Clinton’s 2017 book called?</p><p class="answer__text">What Happened?</p><p class="answer__text">What Happened.</p><p class="answer__text">What Happened?!</p><p class="answer__text">WTF?</p><p class="question__text">The French Socialist candidate who won 6% of the vote in the first round of the 2017 presidential election was called:</p><p class="answer__text">François Hollande.</p><p class="answer__text">Jean-Luc Mélenchon.</p><p class="answer__text">Benoît Hamon. </p><p class="answer__text">Edith Piaf.</p><p class="question__text">Why did a 5kg courgette make the news?</p><p class="answer__text">It was grown by Jeremy Corbyn.</p><p class="answer__text">Tabloid newspapers claimed it had to be pulped as a result of EU rules on oversized vegetables.</p><p class="answer__text">It was mistaken for a second world war bomb. </p><p class="answer__text">It was too explicit for a shop window in Tunbridge Wells.</p><p class="question__text">Where was Prue Leith when she tweeted the name of the winner of The Great British Bake Off 12 hours before the final was broadcast?</p><p class="answer__text">Bhutan.</p><p class="answer__text">Basingstoke.</p><p class="answer__text">Bolivia.</p><p class="answer__text">Botswana.</p><p class="question__text">Former Lib Dem Leader Tim Farron asked a voter in the 2017 general election campaign to “smell my …”?</p><p class="answer__text">Spaniel. </p><p class="answer__text">Spliff.</p><p class="answer__text"> Scratch’n’sniff manifesto.</p><p class="answer__text">Sandals.</p><p class="question__text">TV legend Bruce Forsyth died in August. In which year did he make his television debut?</p><p class="answer__text">1936.</p><p class="answer__text">1939.</p><p class="answer__text">1942.</p><p class="answer__text">1845.</p><p class="question__text">In 2017, widespread protests broke out over the price of what well-known snack?</p><p class="answer__text">Freddos.</p><p class="answer__text">Beluga caviar.</p><p class="answer__text">Milk tray chocolates.</p><p class="answer__text">Frazzles.</p><p class="question__text">What did I do for a constituent as part of my 2017 election campaign, which attracted media coverage?</p><p class="answer__text">Take her dog Biscuits for a walk.</p><p class="answer__text">Mow her lawn. </p><p class="answer__text">Pump up her flat tyre.</p><p class="answer__text">Paint a work of abstract impressionism inspired by Jackson Pollock.</p><p class="question__text">I did a rendition of a famous 80s song on Channel 4’s The Last Leg. Which song?</p><p class="answer__text">Wake Me Up Before You Go-Go.</p><p class="answer__text">Tainted Love.</p><p class="answer__text">Take on Me.</p><p class="answer__text">YMCA.</p><p class="question__text">I tried to sing a death metal song when I sat in for Jeremy Vine on BBC Radio 2 in June, learning from a lead singer of a death metal group. Which group was it?</p><p class="answer__text">Napalm Death.</p><p class="answer__text">Cannibal Corpse.</p><p class="answer__text">Carcass.</p><p class="answer__text">Edge of Sanity.</p><p class="question__text">Which policy was once described by David Cameron as living in a “Marxist universe” and adopted this year by the government?</p><p class="answer__text">Energy price cap.</p><p class="answer__text">Compulsory purchase of land.</p><p class="answer__text">Executive pay limits.</p><p class="answer__text">Nationalisation of the UK’s biggest 200 companies.</p><p class="question__text">What is my hugely successful viral podcast called (available to download on all good apps)?</p><p class="answer__text">I Wuz Robbed.</p><p class="answer__text">Coalition of Chaos.</p><p class="answer__text">Reasons to be Cheerful. </p><p class="answer__text">Saving My Bacon.</p><p class="question__text">Which pet-loving politician is the odd one out?</p><p class="answer__text">Jacinda Ardern. </p><p class="answer__text">Theresa May.</p><p class="answer__text">Jeremy Corbyn.</p><p class="answer__text">Philip Hammond.</p><p class="question__text">Which US power-player is the odd one out?</p><p class="answer__text">Thomas Paine.</p><p class="answer__text">Elon Musk.</p><p class="answer__text">Mark Zuckerberg.</p><p class="answer__text">Hillary Clinton. </p><p class="question__text">Which parent is the odd one out? </p><p class="answer__text">George Clooney.</p><p class="answer__text">Ronaldo.</p><p class="answer__text">Danny DeVito.</p><p class="answer__text">Beyoncé.</p><p class="question__text">Which errant company is the odd one out?</p><p class="answer__text">Pepsi.</p><p class="answer__text">Dove.</p><p class="answer__text">United Airlines.</p><p class="answer__text">Tsukuba Express.</p><p class="question__text">None of the names below were candidates at the 2017 general election apart from one. Who was the real 2017 candidate?</p><p class="answer__text">Lord Snooty.</p><p class="answer__text">Mr Fish Finger.</p><p class="answer__text">Nick the Flying Brick.</p><p class="answer__text">Auntie BBC Ate My Hamster.</p><p class="score__min-score">25 and above.</p><p class="score__title">You’re a master of the Miliverse. Make yourself a celebratory bacon sandwich. No photos.</p><p class="score__min-score">24 and above.</p><p class="score__title">You’re a master of the Miliverse. Make yourself a celebratory bacon sandwich. No photos.</p><p class="score__min-score">23 and above.</p><p class="score__title">You’re a master of the Miliverse. Make yourself a celebratory bacon sandwich. No photos.</p><p class="score__min-score">22 and above.</p><p class="score__title">You’re a master of the Miliverse. Make yourself a celebratory bacon sandwich. No photos.</p><p class="score__min-score">21 and above.</p><p class="score__title">You’re a master of the Miliverse. Make yourself a celebratory bacon sandwich. No photos.</p><p class="score__min-score">20 and above.</p><p class="score__title">You’re an honoured citizen of the Miliverse. Edstone on the way.</p><p class="score__min-score">19 and above.</p><p class="score__title">You’re an honoured citizen of the Miliverse. Edstone on the way.</p><p class="score__min-score">18 and above.</p><p class="score__title">You’re an honoured citizen of the Miliverse. Edstone on the way.</p><p class="score__min-score">17 and above.</p><p class="score__title">You’re an honoured citizen of the Miliverse. Edstone on the way.</p><p class="score__min-score">16 and above.</p><p class="score__title">You’re an honoured citizen of the Miliverse. Edstone on the way.</p><p class="score__min-score">15 and above.</p><p class="score__title">You’re a Miliverse apprentice. By next year you could be a citizen.</p><p class="score__min-score">14 and above.</p><p class="score__title">You’re a Miliverse apprentice. By next year you could be a citizen.</p><p class="score__min-score">13 and above.</p><p class="score__title">You’re a Miliverse apprentice. By next year you could be a citizen.</p><p class="score__min-score">12 and above.</p><p class="score__title">You’re a Miliverse apprentice. By next year you could be a citizen.</p><p class="score__min-score">11 and above.</p><p class="score__title">You’re a Miliverse apprentice. By next year you could be a citizen.</p><p class="score__min-score">10 and above.</p><p class="score__title">You’re a Miliverse apprentice. By next year you could be a citizen.</p><p class="score__min-score">9 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Obviously you found the news unbearable and so didn’t pay attention.     <item>
      <title>Alexandra's jive to judge Shirley: the best bits of Strictly Come Dancing 2017</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/dec/18/strictly-come-dancing-best-bits-joe-mcfadden</link>
      <description><p>It’s been a vintage year for Strictly with changes in the judging lineup working well and a litany of great dances from jives and quicksteps to Argentine tangos</p><p>So in the end it was Joe and Katya who lifted the Glitterball <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/live/2017/dec/16/strictly-come-dancing-final-live" style="background-color: white;">on Saturday</a>, after one of the hardest-fought Strictly finals in years. It brought the curtain down on the 15<sup>th</sup> series of Strictly Come Dancing, with <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/dec/17/strictly-come-dancing-most-popular-series-ends-viewers" style="background-color: white;">impressive viewer numbers</a> and a format that doesn’t seem to age. This year was no exception: the series was packed with showstopping dancing and gave us plenty of laughs along the way. I’ve whittled it down to my five favourite moments, but feel free to add yours in the comment box below.<br></p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/dec/18/joe-mcfadden-celebrate-strictly-come-dancing-victory-whiskies-sleep">Joe McFadden: I'll celebrate Strictly victory with whiskies and sleep</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/dec/18/strictly-come-dancing-best-bits-joe-mcfadden">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Joe McFadden: I'll celebrate Strictly victory with whiskies and sleep</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/dec/18/joe-mcfadden-celebrate-strictly-come-dancing-victory-whiskies-sleep</link>
      <description><p>Former Holby City actor says he is looking forward to a rest but plans to keep dancing after winning BBC show with Katya Jones</p><p>Strictly champions each have a unique way of dealing with winning the perennially popular Saturday evening show, and Joe McFadden’s is perhaps unsurprising, given he is the show’s first Scottish winner and the oldest contestant to take home the Glitterball trophy.</p><p>Asked what he planned to do in the wake of his triumph, the former Holby City actor said he was looking forward to sinking a couple of whiskies before sleeping for a week. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/dec/17/strictly-winners-2017-joe-mcfadden-katya-jones">Strictly crowns Katya Jones and Joe McFadden in a sea of schmaltz</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/dec/18/joe-mcfadden-celebrate-strictly-come-dancing-victory-whiskies-sleep">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Strictly Come Dancing and racial prejudice | Letters</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/dec/17/strictly-come-dancing-and-racial-prejudice</link>
      <description><strong>Tim Bale</strong> thinks more research is needed before deciding whether ethnicity affects a contestant’s chance of winning, <strong>Sue Boulding</strong> says some took against Alexandra Burke because they thought she had an unfair head start, while <strong>Alex More</strong> points to the expected success of Anthony Joshua in another public vote<p>I’m a huge Strictly fan and, although I was happy to see <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/dec/17/strictly-winners-2017-joe-mcfadden-katya-jones" title="">Joe McFadden win this year</a>, I would have been equally happy to see the breathtakingly brilliant Alexandra Burke get her hands on the coveted glitterball trophy. I therefore read with interest your article (<a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/dec/16/alexandra-burke-and-the-trouble-with-reality-tv-and-race-strictly" title="">Strictly’s Burke the latest black contestant to fall foul of harsh reality TV</a>, 16 December), which suggested your research had indicated that BAME (and particularly female BAME) contestants were far more likely to leave the show early.</p><p>This may well have been the case so far, but strictly speaking (if you’ll forgive the pun) the statistics don’t really allow us to say with any certainty yet that it was all down to their ethnicity or their sex. We’d have to have more contests – and therefore more contestants – to get truly convincing proof of that. We’d also have to control for all the other factors that might make a difference to a contestant’s success: for instance, athleticism, fame and, like this year’s winner, being a&nbsp;popular cast member in a long-running soap opera.<br><strong>Tim Bale</strong><br><em>Professor of politics, Queen Mary University of London</em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/dec/17/strictly-come-dancing-and-racial-prejudice">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Strictly Come Dancing's most popular series yet ends with 13.1m viewers</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/dec/17/strictly-come-dancing-most-popular-series-ends-viewers</link>
      <description><p>Finale fails to beat 2010’s high, but show has pulled in average 11m viewers each week – beating last year’s record of 10.9m</p><p>Strictly Come Dancing concluded the most popular series in its 14-year history on Saturday night with 13.1 million viewers tuning in at the peak of the spangled finale. </p><p>The 2017 final, in which the former Holby City actor Joe McFadden and his partner Katya Jones were crowned champions, failed to beat the viewing figures of the most-watched final, in 2010, which peaked at 14.3 million.</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">So deserved! Massive congratulations to <a href="https://twitter.com/mrjoemcfadden?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">@mrjoemcfadden</a> and <a href="https://twitter.com/Mrs_katjones?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">@Mrs_katjones</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/bbcstrictly?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">@bbcstrictly</a> 2017 winners!  <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/Strictly?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">#Strictly</a> <a href="https://t.co/mqxn9Qdfiy">pic.twitter.com/mqxn9Qdfiy</a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/dec/17/strictly-come-dancing-most-popular-series-ends-viewers">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Strictly crowns Katya Jones and Joe McFadden in a sea of schmaltz</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/dec/17/strictly-winners-2017-joe-mcfadden-katya-jones</link>
      <description><p>It was a sparkling sugar-rush of nerves for the BBC Strictly Come Dancing final, a culmination of the winning formula of fake tan, sequins and a little controversy</p><p>As the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/live/2017/dec/16/strictly-come-dancing-final-live"><em>Strictly Come Dancing</em></a> final unfolded, amid all the glitz, camaraderie and spangles, a mutinous thought formed in the showbiz ether – had this series missed the Ed-factor?</p><p>Well, perhaps a bit. Few could forget the former shadow Labour chancellor Ed Ball’s appearance in the last series, including his now infamous <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Czqtjk_iGFU">Bafta-nominated Gangnam Style</a> routine, where he danced as though demonstrating the tragic effects of lifelong undiagnosed rickets.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/live/2017/dec/16/strictly-come-dancing-final-live">Strictly Come Dancing final – as it happened</a> </p><p>This had been a remarkably good-humoured series, topped off by a zesty competitive final</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/dec/17/strictly-winners-2017-joe-mcfadden-katya-jones">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Bruce Forsyth remembered by Anton du Beke</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/dec/17/bruce-forsyth-remembered-by-anton-du-beke</link>
      <description><p><strong>22 February 1928 – 8 August 2017</strong><br>The former Strictly dancer on meeting his boyhood hero, the veteran entertainer whose career spanned 75 years: ‘He could do anything’<br><br><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2017/dec/17/sam-shepard-remembered-by-johnny-dark-obituary-2017">• Sam Shepard remembered by Johnny Dark</a></p><p>I grew up watching Brucie on the telly. We all did. He was there at the very beginning of TV – with <em>Sunday Night at the London Palladium</em> – and right up until the past couple of years. He was what they used to call the triple threat, the full package: actor, singer, dancer. But he was actually so much more than that. He was the multiple threat. He didn’t just act, sing and dance, he could host, tell gags, play musical instruments – he could do anything.</p><p>It’s quite a thing when your boyhood hero becomes your friend</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/dec/17/bruce-forsyth-remembered-by-anton-du-beke">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Strictly Come Dancing final – as it happened</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/live/2017/dec/16/strictly-come-dancing-final-live</link>
      <description><p>Just four couples made it through, and each pairing had three dances to impress the judges and the viewers – who was this year’s Glitterball winner?</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-16T21:00:37.192Z">9.00pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>So that’s another Strictly year over – it’s been a brilliant series, and I just wanted to say a huge thank you to everyone who has read and shared this liveblog, but most especially those of you who take the time to join in via the comment box every week. This blog has has grown into a very special Strictly community over the years, and it makes writing every week an absolute pleasure. I genuinely can’t thank you enough.</p><p>My liveblogging duties might be over for the year, but there will be a thread on Christmas Day for the Strictly Christmas Special, so you can all chat in the comment box. In the meantime you can find me on Twitter @heidistephens, so do come and say hello.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-16T20:58:47.357Z">8.58pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>And the winner is…JOE AND KATYA!</p><p>WELL. Didn’t think that would actually happen in the end – I thought their showdance might have blown it. Huge congratulations to all of them, incredibly worthy finalists, and a massive well done to Joe and Katya. WHAT A FINAL!</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-16T20:56:23.918Z">8.56pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Oh thank GOODNESS. It’s time to announce the winner! I have no idea who this will be, but my gut says Debbie. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-16T20:55:05.140Z">8.55pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>OK I’m totally montaged out now. Crown a winner, I’m done. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-16T20:53:10.987Z">8.53pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Anyone for another montage? I feel like we haven’t had quite enough.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-16T20:51:21.555Z">8.51pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Hooray, a trailer for the Christmas Special! I won’t be liveblogging, but I’ll open a comment thread for you.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-16T20:50:42.540Z">8.50pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Time to bring back the stars of Strictly for a final group dance! Feels like several decades have passed since Chizzy was on the show. Likewise Reverend Richard, they were both fabulous. Brian falls off a wall, and Charlotte is still joyously wooden. Simon doesn’t do anything either, but YES Aston is back. ANTON DRINK. Jonnie’s had a haircut and Aston pops in a backflip, as a reminder of the showdance we missed (I’ll never get over this). Susan and Kevin throw in a bit of Morecambe and Wise, and Davood does his bum lift. </p><p>I really wanted Mollie and AJ to snog at the end. Why do they keep disappointing me? <br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-16T20:44:56.996Z">8.44pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>I feel like this final has been going for several years. I’m now older than Debbie, and parts of Bruno.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-16T20:42:42.034Z">8.42pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Time for another montage! If you’re still standing, DRINK.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-16T20:42:00.056Z">8.42pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Is it time to crown a winner yet? How is there 20 minutes left? Voting has closed!</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-16T20:40:03.226Z">8.40pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>How is there no-one dancing to this? Do we have to look at Ed Sheeran? Why would anyone want to do that?</p><p>Oh thank goodness. Karen and Pasha are here to save us. But not Kevin, because there are Alleged Domestic Issues chez Clifton.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-16T20:38:00.435Z">8.38pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Goodness, that montage went on for weeks. </p><p>IT’S TIME FOR ED SHEERAN, singing this year’s entry for this “first dance at a wedding” award. DRIIIIIINK.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-16T20:34:26.634Z">8.34pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>OK, I’m quite tired now. 25 minutes to go, STAY WITH ME.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-16T20:33:22.611Z">8.33pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Time for another montage! DRINK! </p><p>I’ve loved this series, it’s been great fun and you guys have been a weekend refuge in a stressful year. Thank you. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-16T20:31:30.048Z">8.31pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Time for a recap! DRINK! We scored a full house on bingo hours ago.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-16T20:31:06.880Z">8.31pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>So the irrelevant leaderboard is as follows: Alexandra, Joe, Debbie and Gemma.</p><p>I predict that Debbie will win, for having the best partnership, doing a banging Argentine, and waving the flag for women of a certain age. But I’m really not sure, the glitterball could genuinely be taken by any of them. How amazing is that?<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-16T20:28:07.972Z">8.28pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Chizzy is crying. DRINK!<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-16T20:27:42.903Z">8.27pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Darcey loved it - the perfect end to a great final. Shirley thinks Joe has turned into a magnificent dancer. Bruno thought all the couples have been incredible, but isn’t specific about Joe. Craig thought it was fab.u.lous.</p><p>I feel like I’m being mean now. I do think Joe is great, but that Charleston just wasn’t my cup of tea.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-16T20:24:01.262Z">8.24pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Nope, still don’t like it. It’s full of character and fun, but Joe’s swivel is a bit laboured and it just all feels a bit clunky. Not even the performance can save it, I have no idea why they chose this. <br></p><p>Oh hang on, the judges loved it. That’s why.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-16T20:22:29.524Z">8.22pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>And finally for this year, it’s Joe and Katya! Joe and Katya have never been in the dance-off and have the most inventive choreography, so there’s no doubt they could lift the Glitterball later. </p><p>I’d originally excluded Gemma and Aljaz from tonight’s top spot, but Aljaz knows exactly what it takes to win, and Gemma could easily take the journey prize if she find can find an extra gear for their Showdance.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-16T17:40:37.451Z">5.40pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>So who’s going to win this year? My highly unscientific Twitter poll says Joe and Katya, but last year everyone said Danny and Oti and ranked Ore and Joanne last, so what does Twitter know.</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">So, who's going to win this year's <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/strictly?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">#strictly</a>? (NB most of you were wrong last year)</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-15T13:39:43.807Z">1.39pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Evening all, and a very warm welcome to the 2017 Strictly Come Dancing Grand Final liveblog! After three months of dance, drama, debating and tapping away at this keyboard like a demon, we’ve whittled down our original 15 couples to a final four – Alexandra and Gorka, Debbie and Giovannia, Gemma and Aljaz and Joe and Katyal. All that’s keeping one of them from holding aloft the Strictly glitterball is three final dances. </p><p>So here’s the plan for tonight’s show – all four couples are dancing three routines back to back – a dance picked by the Judges, a brand new Showdance and each couple’s favourite dance of the series. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/live/2017/dec/16/strictly-come-dancing-final-live">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Alexandra Burke and the trouble with reality TV and race</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/dec/16/alexandra-burke-and-the-trouble-with-reality-tv-and-race-strictly</link>
      <description><p>As a brilliant dancer fails to win votes on Strictly week after week, an unsettling interpretation emerges: that racial anxieties are the problem</p><p>Few contestants have dominated the Strictly Come Dancing dancefloor like Alexandra Burke has this year. She received the first 10 of the season for her jive to Tina Turner’s Proud Mary, performed a flawless, Mary Poppins-themed charleston and impressed the judges with her salsa and her Viennese waltz.</p><p>Despite her technical brilliance, Burke has found herself repeatedly in the bottom two – as voted for by the British public. And some observers have perceived a contempt for her, from both the media and the public, that is unlike anything directed towards her fellow contestants. </p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Have to say the thinly veiled racism directed at <a href="https://twitter.com/joannajarjue?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">@joannajarjue</a> on this seasons Apprentice was hard to watch. She was no more “confrontational” than anyone else.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/dec/16/alexandra-burke-and-the-trouble-with-reality-tv-and-race-strictly">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Strictly Come Dancing semi-final results – as it happened</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/live/2017/dec/09/strictly-come-dancing-semi-final-watch-live</link>
      <description><p>The competition got serious with a two-dance semi-final, but which of the five remaining celebrities performed best under pressure, and who didn’t make the Grand Final? <br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:59:07.852Z">7.59pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Thank you all for joining in and being amazing as always – you can find me on Twitter @heidistephens if you’d like to say hello, otherwise I’ll see you back here next Saturday for a 6.30pm start. Dress code: FULL GLITTER. See you then!</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:58:55.442Z">7.58pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>So that’s it for Strictly until next week’s GRAND FINAL – never mind the celebs, what could be better than Gorka, Giovanni, Aljaz and Katya? It’s going to be a good-un, I reckon, despite the fact that they’ve messed with the format and it’s now a non-stop 2.5 HOURS WITH NO BREAK. My fingers will be worn down to NUBS.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:58:45.654Z">7.58pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Mollie and AJ dance their final dance to Can’t Smile Without You by Barry Manilow. I really want them to snog each other’s faces off, but they don’t. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:56:18.554Z">7.56pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Mollie and AJ say lovely things about each other, and because it’s the semi-final, they get a Best Bits. <br></p><p>Poor AJ, another Strictly ending with a semi.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:54:17.845Z">7.54pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Which means MOLLIE AND AJ are leaving Strictly. On the upside, it gives them more time for heavy petting. On the downside, they’ve been kind of adorable and incredibly likeable, and I feel like Mollie has genuinely had a ‘Journey’.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:53:54.190Z">7.53pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Craig saves Gemma and Aljaz, but clearly a tough decision. Darcey and Bruno do the same, so GEMMA AND ALJAZ are through to the final. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:51:24.683Z">7.51pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Time for Gemma and Aljaz’s Tango. Feels like Gemma is doing her best to find another gear; she’s not going without a fight. </p><p>I totally can’t call this. What will the judges do?</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:49:48.971Z">7.49pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>OK, time for another spin of Mollie and AJ’s Waltz. Regardless of whether these two are a couple or it’s all for show, you can’t deny they have incredible chemistry, and it makes all the difference in a dance like this. Definitely better than last night, but will it be enough?</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:46:00.283Z">7.46pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>“Strictly has brought happiness back into my life” says Debbie. After spending decades in the shadow of her husband and clearly struggling to cope with his loss, it makes me incredibly happy to see her sparkling in the spotlight. GO DEBBIE. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:42:32.757Z">7.42pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>OOOH, this is going to be interesting – really can’t predict how this is going to go. Both dances scored the same, but it felt like the judges preferred Mollie and AJ’s Waltz to Gemma and Aljaz’s Tango. I LOVE a bit of dance off peril.</p><p>(Also well done public voters, you did the right thing).</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:41:57.367Z">7.41pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>So who is joining Gemma and Aljaz in tonight’s dance off? DEBBIE AND GIOVANNI are safely through to the final, which means MOLLIE AND AJ in the bottom two. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:40:51.822Z">7.40pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>We must be getting near the end of the series; we’ve already started rolling out the montages. It’s been a valiant effort to make ‘dance debrief’ stick, but it never quite worked.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:35:22.475Z">7.35pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>I can’t think of a better way to spend an evening than watching Aljaz and Janette contempo-wafting to Craig David. </p><p>Just me? FINE.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:34:00.617Z">7.34pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>The lyrics suggest Craig and Dan from Bastille hit the Strictly Come Bingo last night. In fact, I might make this our liveblog anthem:</p><p>This gonna be a heavy night/Way too many drinks for me to start it</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:33:16.347Z">7.33pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Time for a musical interlude, courtesy of Craig David and Bastille, who have done a duet called “I Know You”. As mentioned in last night’s comment box, I’m a massive fan of Craig David and absolutely love this song, so shush.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:33:03.819Z">7.33pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Don’t know about you, but I could watch half-naked Gorka talking about his feelings all day.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:32:09.334Z">7.32pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>I’ve realised what Claudia’s dress reminds me of – it’s from the Beauty and The Beast dance scene, worn by the Beast. <br></p><p>Tale as old as time...<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:29:44.150Z">7.29pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>First couple in tonight’s dance off: GEMMA AND ALJAZ. </p><p>If they’re up against Mollie and AJ, they could stay. But if it’s Debbie and Giovanni, they’re on their way home. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:27:57.788Z">7.27pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>So who is the first couple safely through to next week’s GRAND FINAL? It’s JOE AND KATYA (hooray!). They’re joined by ALEXANDRA AND GORKA (double hooray!). <br></p><p>Well done great British public.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:25:01.335Z">7.25pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Joe and Katya, Alexandra and Gorka and Debbie and Giovanni all shone, whilst Mollie and Gemma didn’t quite make the grade, but still great to watch. I watched Mollie and AJ’s Samba again today and still thoroughly enjoyed it, I think I’m just a sucker for a Samba (of any quality). <br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:23:48.891Z">7.23pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Last night on Strictly: an absolute corker of a semi. Great dancing, fab costumes, brilliant (and dance-appropriate) music, stunning choreography, no comedy VTs – my idea of Strictly heaven, long may it continue. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:21:45.963Z">7.21pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>TESS AND CLAUDIA DRESS WATCH: Tess in a black shroud with her head through the wrong hole, Claudia in the most bizarre turquoise number with a frilly bib. NOPE NOPE NOPE.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:20:21.045Z">7.20pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Tonight’s pro dance is a Lindyhop special, just to remind us that it’s a great dance and should probably replace the Rumba. Strictly dancers are accompanied by some Lindyhop pros, who manage to make it look like the coolest thing ever. Look at the adorable breakdancing kiddies!<br></p><p>I imagine Aston’s showdance would have looked a bit like this. Bring back Aston.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:18:00.813Z">7.18pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>And we’re off! Absorb the joy of these opening credits, you only get to see Brian’s thumb one more time. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:16:15.066Z">7.16pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>That’s it for this year’s Countryfile liveblog. It was a bit half-hearted, but frankly nobody was paying and I was usually eating dinner at the same time. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T19:07:27.167Z">7.07pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Tonight’s Countryfile Casual Weatherperson is the delightful Sarah Keith-Lucas in ill-fitting coral polyester. A whole season without a single sighting of Tomasz Schafernaker. I am bereft. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T18:58:16.787Z">6.58pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Imagine being a slightly confused senior in a care home and finding an alpaca in the TV room. It would finish you off. <br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T18:55:06.311Z">6.55pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>How to order a Countryfile calendar:</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T18:48:35.265Z">6.48pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Tiny piglets on Countryfile! They might all be dead from piggie plague soon, but lovely nonetheless.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-10T18:47:48.939Z">6.47pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Evening all, and welcome back for tonight’s semi-final results! We have five couples left, but only four can make the Grand Final next weekend. It should be Mollie and AJ to go really, but nobody is safe in the sequinned world of Strictly. <br></p><p>Kick off is at 7.15pm – in the meantime enjoy our FINAL pre-Strictly Countryfile of the year. If you haven’t bought your Countryfile 
 <strike>
   naked weathermen 
 </strike> cute animals calendar yet, you’re leaving it a bit late. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T20:21:45.927Z">8.21pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Goodness, that was intense. Thank you all for joining in and being marvellous – I’m back tomorrow at 7.20pm for the very last Countryfile round-up/Sunday Results show of the season. Wear something casual, maybe in plaid. Enjoy the rest of your Saturday, and I’ll see you tomorrow! </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T20:21:00.762Z">8.21pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>And Mollie said Journey! DRINK DRINK DRINK HOUSE<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T20:20:40.969Z">8.20pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Time for a begging VT - all we need is for someone to say the ‘J’ word and we’ve got a Bingo full house. <br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T20:18:48.687Z">8.18pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>So who isn’t making next week’s Grand Final? By rights it should be Gemma and Aljaz and Mollie and AJ in the bottom two this week, but to be honest nobody is safe these days. <br></p><p>If it did come down to these two, however, I really couldn’t call who would go - Mollie and AJ’s Waltz could very easily trump Gemma and Aljaz’s Tango (I can’t imagine either of them going near the Samba/Rumba again, they’re not MAD).<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T20:16:53.718Z">8.16pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>The dancing is over, and the voting lines are open. I take back everything I said about semi-final quality – I thought there was some great dancing this evening. Also Oti’s dress gets a ten from me.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T20:15:31.566Z">8.15pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Scores: 8,9,9,10 (DRINK) - a total of 36 for Debbie and Giovanni.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T20:14:47.686Z">8.14pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Bruno thought it was Strictly gorgeous, and if Debbie doesn’t make the final he’ll wear Darcey’s tutu, no knickers and a tiara. OKAY THEN. Craig is deducting a point for being too long out of hold (TEN SECOND RULE ILLEGAL LIFT DRINK), but other than that he loved it. Darcey thought it was stunningly effortless and elegant. Shirley thought it was an amazing way to close the show. I concur. <br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T20:12:20.451Z">8.12pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Giovanni is also in tails, Strictly you are spoiling us. Some gorgeous outfits this evening, and Debbie’s is no exception. </p><p>As expected, this Foxtrot is glorious - Debbie and Giovanni have the most unexpected chemistry and I’ve loved watching them dance. Debbie totally deserves to be in the final, she’s incredible.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T20:09:27.153Z">8.09pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>And finally, it’s Debbie and Giovanni! Their second dance is the Foxtrot to ‘Isn’t She Lovely’ by Stevie Wonder. I love this song, and on the coldest of cold winter nights, have every hope that this Foxtrot is going to be filled with sunshine and rainbows. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T20:07:50.445Z">8.07pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Scores: 8,8,8,8 - a total of 32 for Gemma and Aljaz.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T20:06:39.645Z">8.06pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Shirley thought Gemma did very well, and Bruno thought it had a great sense of purpose, but it got a bit steppy. Craig wanted more v-shaping and Gemma’s hand wasn’t quite right, but it had great attack. Darcey loved the determination from Gemma, very nice work.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T20:05:16.250Z">8.05pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Loving Gemma’s don’t-mess-with-me dress and hair, it’s a great look for her. This Tango has plenty of punch and some nice footwork from Gemma, but it needs about 25% more for me – just a bit lacking in drive and attitude. But still love this partnership; Aljaz can do no wrong as far as I’m concerned.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T20:02:53.915Z">8.02pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>It’s time for Gemma and Aljaz! Their second dance is the Tango to ‘My Sharona’ by The Knack (but it’s the Dave Arch version of the Royal Blood cover, so don’t shout at me). After a fair-to-middling Rumba, Gemma needs to put her game face on and give it full Tango fierceness.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T20:00:51.277Z">8.00pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>SO much hugging. DRINK.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T20:00:43.225Z">8.00pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Scores: 8,8,8,8 - a total of 32 for Mollie and AJ.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:59:37.717Z">7.59pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Darcey thought it had all the elements of a serene, romantic waltz, and Mollie held her posture until the very end (apart from the final bit). Shirley thought it was much better than the Samba, and Mollie’s pivots were lovely despite the little mistake. Bruno liked the control and it was classic ballroom waltz - much much better. Craig agrees that there were a couple of issues, but Mollie has redeemed herself. </p><p>Apparently being AJ’s partner comes with a free shoulder massage. Bonus.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:56:59.730Z">7.56pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Oh goodness me, Mollie’s dress is glorious, and AJ is actually in tails. You can’t deny these two look hopelessly in love. Lovely frame from Mollie, but a couple of wobbly moments. That said, full of romance and entirely beautiful - enjoyed that very much.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:53:58.615Z">7.53pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>How do you follow that? It’s Mollie and AJ! Their second dance this evening is the Waltz to ‘Angel’ by Sarah McLachlan. This is basically a first-dance-at-a-wedding song, so let’s assume Mollie and AJ’s showmance is on a fast track, and she’ll be pregnant by next Saturday. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:52:37.272Z">7.52pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>If Alexandra is still in the dance-off, I will be very sad. <br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:52:06.890Z">7.52pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Scores: 10,10,10,10 - drink until you can drink no more.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:50:57.609Z">7.50pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Craig thought it was FAB.U.LOUS. Darcey wanted to be at Alexandra’s private disco, it was a great routine and if Alex isn’t in the final, Darcey will wear Bruno’s speedos (Ew. EWW). Shirley loved the rhythm, and it was party time all the way. Bruno could feel the heat, and starts singing Whitney Houston. He’s properly lost it.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:48:31.407Z">7.48pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>After last week’s dress horror, Alex has been rewarded by wardrobe this week. Loads of Salsa style and great basics, lovely footwork, tons of energy and fabulous lifts, including a crotch/face spin that goes on for about a week. LOVED that. <br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:46:05.722Z">7.46pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Next up it’s Alexandra and Gorka! Their second dance is the Salsa to ‘Finally’ by Cece Peniston. This is a solid gold choon, and Alex’s Latin has improved significantly over the course of this series, so I have high hopes for this. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:44:17.167Z">7.44pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Scores: 8,9,9,9 - a total of 35 for Joe and Katya. Can’t imagine him not being in the final, somehow.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:43:22.570Z">7.43pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Bruno liked the modern twist, but it still true to the Argentine Tango. Shame about Joe losing balance at the end. Craig thought the walking steps were a bit ploddy and it needed a looser leg in the ganchos, but the inventiveness played off. Darcey (OMG how big is her ring?) loved how daring it was, and Shirley liked how Joe and Katya pushed the boundaries despite the wobbly bit. <br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:40:19.758Z">7.40pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Oh hello casual BDSM Joe, dancing in front of a mirror AGAIN. This is all quite intense, but a bit bouncy for an Argentine and not nearly sharp enough. Some lovely timing though, but a bit wobbly on the lifts and not sure about the “how strong is my core” seesaw lift at the end. Call me old-fashioned, but I like my Argentines to be more Buenos Aires than James Bond(age). <br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:38:04.580Z">7.38pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Time for some second dances, and up first it’s Joe and Katya! Their second dance this evening is the Argentine Tango to ‘Human’ by Rag n’ Bone Man. I question the wisdom of attempting an Argentine at this point of the series, but Katya’s choreography hasn’t let Joe down yet this series, so let’s assume they’re going to pull this off with bells on.</p><p>It feels like ages since we last had a comedy VT. I’m SO happy about this, thank you Strictly big cheeses. <br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:34:31.203Z">7.34pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>DEBBIE’S AGE! DRINK.</p><p>Scores: 7,9,9,9 - a total of 34 for Debbie and Giovanni.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:33:25.746Z">7.33pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Shirley loved Debbie’s bending standing leg and it had some nice swing - a grand job. Bruno loved Debbie’s timing, and she was as “crispy as a kettle crisp” (can someone take a look at Bruno’s meds?). Craig thought it lacked retraction and looked a bit spiky and stiff, and he didn’t like Debbie’s Judge Rinder face. Darcey thought it was fast and sweet, and Debbie’s energy is extraordinary.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:31:13.215Z">7.31pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>I love Debbie’s dress, she looks absolutely fabulous. Loads of personality and some very decent kicks and flicks, but it feels quite stiff and laboured in places - a problem Debbie has had with Latin all season. Great fun thought, and shirtless Giovanni is making up for the fact my heating isn’t working properly. <br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:28:34.454Z">7.28pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>It’s time for Debbie and Giovanni! Their first dance is the Jive to ‘I’m So Excited’ by the Pointer Sisters. This raises the terrifying prospect of a ‘disco Jive’ which should not and never has been A Thing. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:26:52.030Z">7.26pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Scores: 7,8,7,8 - a total of 30 for Gemma and Aljaz. <br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:25:40.771Z">7.25pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Darcey liked the intensity of their eye contact, but she needs to bring that through her body. Shirley thought Gemma has lovely legs, but it lacked musicality and continuous movement. Bruno thought it was sensual but not smutty - even grandma would approve - but it needed more flow. Craig thought Gemma’s upper body was inanimate, but the hip action was great. <br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:22:59.302Z">7.22pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Not sure about Gemma’s muppet dress, but she has some lovely hip action. It’s very pretty, but like every other Rumba this season it’s all rather platonic and safe. I remain unmoved. <br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:20:28.945Z">7.20pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>It’s time for Gemma and Aljaž! Their first dance is the Rumba to ‘Beneath Your Beautiful’ by Labrinth featuring Emeli Sandé. I’m a bit worried about this – a Rumba in a semi-final is a very dangerous game indeed, and I’m not sure Gemma has the grace to do it justice. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:18:48.345Z">7.18pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Scores: 4,7,7,6 - a total of 24 for Mollie and AJ. Oh come on Craig, that was a bit mean.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:17:32.298Z">7.17pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Craig thought the palm trees had more bounce and the timing was awful, he basically hated it. Darcey thought Mollie looked like a gold goddess, but it wasn’t Mollie’s dance. Shirley loved the solo pieces, and how Mollie was going for it. Bruno thought that Mollie missed the flight to Brazil, and the timing was all over the place. </p><p>I didn’t actually think it was that bad, at least Mollie looked like she was having fun. <br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:14:29.920Z">7.14pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Mollie is giving it full Shakira hips and she means BUSINESS. I quite like drunken abandon Mollie - a bit clunky in the footwork and the Samba rolls could be more pronounced, but I actually really enjoyed that. <br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:12:24.640Z">7.12pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Next up it’s Mollie and AJ! Their first dance tonight is the Samba to ‘Whenever, Wherever’ by Shakira. This is the one that includes the lyrics “lucky that my breasts are small and humble, so you don’t confuse them with mountains”. I mean, it’s an easy mistake to make. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:09:50.956Z">7.09pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Scores: 9,10,10,10 (DRINK) - a total of 39 for Alex and Gorka.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:08:25.642Z">7.08pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Bruno loved the soft, dreamy quality, like the softest pashmina you want to hug all night (OK BRUNO). Craig points out that her feet didn’t come together at one point, but otherwise beautiful. Darcey loved the ethereal quality - it was graceful and elegant. Shirley thought it was an emotional experience, it was sincere and stunning.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:05:48.851Z">7.05pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Well this is divine. A heartfelt dance of love and joy and pain and everything in between. I couldn’t give the smallest hoot how much dancing she’s done before this show, I could watch these two dance all night. That was beautiful.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:03:37.808Z">7.03pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Next up it’s Alexandra and Gorka! Their first dance this evening is a Viennese Waltz to the Dave Arch version of Tina Arena’s version of R.E.M’s ‘Everybody Hurts’ (do keep up). I suspect this is going to be incredibly emotional and haunting after the couple of weeks Burko has had, and I have tissues on standby.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:02:11.053Z">7.02pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Ore has brought his Glitterball back, and does the Terms &amp; Conditions while he’s there. Thanks Ore.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T19:00:37.768Z">7.00pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Scores: 8,9,9,9 - a total of 35 for Joe and Katya.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T18:59:49.448Z">6.59pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Shirley thought it was a glorious way to open the semi-final - it had exquisite timing. Bruno loved the complicated lifts and the side-to-side sections. Craig thought it lost a little balance and it needed to be smoother, but otherwise charismatic and wonderful. Darcey (BUDGIE CAGE EARRINGS) loved the style and glamour.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T18:57:20.487Z">6.57pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Katya’s dress is to die for, and Joe doesn’t look so bad either. This is a rather lovely jazzy affair, with plenty of swing and sway and a nice section out of hold from Joe. The transitions into the lifts are a bit clunky, but otherwise rather fabulous. Enjoyed very much.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T18:55:36.446Z">6.55pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Anyway, let’s get on with some dancing.</p><p>First up it’s Joe and Katya! Their first dance is the American Smooth to ‘Have You Met Miss Jones?’ By Robbie Williams. This should obviously have been their Week 1 literal dance number, but instead they’ve decided to keep it for Week 12, which makes it look like Joe has got a bit forgetful. Incidentally I’ve never actually met Katya Jones, but I suspect she’s an absolute hoot to go drinking with.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T18:53:43.707Z">6.53pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Oh Tess, what were you thinking? It’s just so...unflattering.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T18:53:25.741Z">6.53pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>This week’s show appears to be sponsored by fringing. Giovanni has forgotten to do his shirt up again, tsk.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T18:52:33.482Z">6.52pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Meanwhile Darcey looks like she has some kind of skin complaint, but Shirley is winning in mermaid sequins.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T18:51:47.332Z">6.51pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>TESS AND CLAUDIA DRESS WATCH: Tess in festive wrapping paper, Claudia in a fringy jumpsuit. Both terrible. </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T18:50:00.387Z">6.50pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>And we’re off! More moody VTs, with bonus dramatic music. They need to be focussed, fearless, fast, flexible, dedicated, determined, disciplined, strong and READY. </p><p>COME ON. I’m excited. <br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T18:47:38.933Z">6.47pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>No Pointless win for me this week, BOO.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T18:42:31.212Z">6.42pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>John Cleese was in Harry Potter and The Philosopher’s Stone, the Romans did irrigation, and Michael Palin did the Pacific Rim.</p><p>Have the got the hang of how Pointless works, do you think?<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T18:33:55.868Z">6.33pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Ooh, I’d go for Charlotte Dujardin, the horse lady.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T18:22:28.793Z">6.22pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Re. tonight’s Pointless, is there anything more deathly tedious than chefs and food writers plugging their restaurants/cook books/food ranges? I’m practically comatose.<br></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-09T18:18:22.006Z">6.18pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>This week’s Stricty Come Bingo – a swing of something you were saving for Christmas for any occurrence of the following:</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2017-12-08T14:40:28.341Z">2.40pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Evening glitter gang, and welcome to this week’s <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/strictly-come-dancing">Strictly Come Dancing</a> liveblog! Despite the first half of this series dragging more than Darcey’s earrings, the second half has flown by and we’ve made it to the SEMI-FINALS. On the upside, it’s nearly Christmas (woo); but on the downside, Strictly finishes next weekend (boo). But no need to cry tinsel tears just yet, we’ve still got this massive semi to look forward to. <br></p><p>Tonight’s show is shaping up to be a defining moment of this series, with each couple tackling TWO DANCES. Strictly history tells us that, much as we’d like this to be 90 minutes of showstopping, toe-tapping dance joy, it’s much more likely to be an under-rehearsed, over-scored hot mess, overseen by a panel of judges who have their coat half on and the engine running. But this year’s Strictly has been full of surprises so far, so you never know.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/live/2017/dec/09/strictly-come-dancing-semi-final-watch-live">Continue reading...</a></description>
